author: Mark Langshaw
title: Uber can continue operating in London after winning key High Court battle - Tech
text: Uber has been given the green light to continue operating in London after winning a significant victory in the High Court.Opponents of the firm argue that determining fares with a smartphone app is the equivalent of using a taxi metre, which are banned in private cars. © Uber The Licensed Taxi Drivers Association and London Private Hire Car Association were calling for Uber to be banned in the UK capital on these grounds, but the High Court has thrown out their allegations.Mr Justice Ouseley ruled that Uber's smartphone app is not in fact "a device for calculating fares", paving the way for the company to continue ferrying customers around London.The app itself does not calculate the cost of the journey, instead relaying information to the firm's servers in California, where the number-crunching takes place.Uber described the ruling as "great news for Londoners and a victory for common sense", but was quick to point out that a decision against them would not have driven them out of London, merely forced them to alter the way they do business. © Uber However, Uber isn't out of the woods yet as the company is involved in a separate dispute with Transport for London. The transport body is planning to introduce new measures that could spell the end of Uber services in London in their current form.The proposals would allegedly include banning operators from showing available cars for hire on smartphone maps, while a minimum five-minute wait time between ordering a private hire vehicle and its arrival could also be introduced.Uber has started up an online petition against the measures, which it claims "make no sense".
